awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Host ocular microbiome and pathogen dynamics: from individual to population-level effects in a songbird
awd_abstract_narration:
Animals harbor many microbes that serve key beneficial roles for their hosts, including protection from disease. While the beneficial roles of many microbes are well established, it is not yet known how these benefits scale up to an entire population and influence disease outbreaks in populations. This award focuses on a contagious 'pink- eye' disease of a common songbird, the house finch. Beneficial bacteria in the eyes of finches can protect birds from developing severe 'pink-eye'. This project examines how the dose of infection impacts the ability of beneficial bacteria to protect birds against disease, and whether beneficial bacteria on the eye can prevent or slow down the spread of this highly contagious disease within a flock of birds. Findings of this research will have important implications for understanding infectious disease outbreaks in wildlife, domestic animals, and humans.  Investigators will engage undergraduate and graduate students in the use of new genomics tools to identify beneficial microbes. Using this study system and others as examples, project personnel will work with the Science Museum of Western Virginia to design a permanent, interactive 'Friendly Microbes' exhibit that illustrates the many ways that microbes benefit their hosts. Graduate students at Virginia Tech will learn how to better communicate science by assisting with the exhibit design and summer workshops associated with the exhibit. 

How the microbiome modulates population-level disease spread depends on how symbionts function in host defense across the natural range of infectious doses, as well as how both 'donating' and 'receiving' the pathogen during transmission is modified by symbionts. This award investigates individual to population-level effects of the ocular microbiome on disease dynamics using a tractable wildlife disease system: a recently emerged conjunctival disease of house finches. Using a suite of mechanistic tools and experimental approaches, this project will: 1) test how pathogen colonization dose mediates the protective role of the resident ocular microbiome for individual finches; 2) determine how the ocular microbiome influences the likelihood of donating versus receiving a conjunctival pathogen during pairwise transmission; and 3) quantify the epidemiological impact of the host ocular microbiome on flock-level infectious disease dynamics. Researchers will examine how microbial symbionts alter both host and pathogen phenotypes relevant for transmission and reveal mechanisms of symbiont-pathogen-host interactions that are most likely to influence population-level disease dynamics. The award will provide training to undergraduate and graduate students in population-wide microbiome research as well as scientific communication. Researchers will develop a new, permanent exhibit at the local museum on the beneficial role of microbes and host workshops to promote scientific literacy on this topic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Animals harbor diverse microbes on almost all body surfaces, including the eye. While some of these bacteria cause disease, many microbes on body surfaces contribute to host health by limiting the severity or spread of harmful microbes. This collaborative project between disease ecologists, community ecologists, and microbiologists examined whether the resident microbes in the eyes of a songbird, the house finch, help protect finches from invasion or spread of a common pink-eye disease that causes high mortality in wild birds. 

We first asked whether the protection provided by resident microbes depends on the amount of harmful bacterial pathogen that a host is exposed to. We predicted that resident microbes could best protect hosts from relatively small doses of pathogen, akin to the small doses many birds receive while eating at bird feeders in the wild. We tested this by exposing birds to one of several pathogen doses after using ocular antibiotics to disrupt the resident microbes in the eyes of some birds, and leaving the ocular microbes of other birds intact. Surprisingly, we did not find protective effects of intact microbial communities, regardless of the pathogen dose. Instead, the overall composition of resident microbes present at the time of infection appeared to be most important. Interestingly, the baseline microbial community in this study differed from the protective structure noted in our prior research.  

We also compared two methods to quantify resident microbes in bird eyes: 1) the DNA-based method most commonly used to sample animal-associated microbes, which may detect inactive or dead microbes; and 2) an RNA-based method, which only detects alive and active microbes. More than three-quarters of the common microbes detected in our DNA samples were also present in paired RNA-based samples from the same birds. This suggests that sampling microbes through DNA robustly captures the most common members of the resident microbe community. However, rarer microbes detected through DNA sampling were less likely to be found in RNA-based samples. Our use of RNA-based methods will help move the field toward understanding who the active players are in a given microbial community.

We next tested whether resident microbes in finch eyes influence disease spread from infected birds to healthy cagemates. The composition of resident microbes in the eyes of infected or healthy birds in each pair did not appear to impact pink-eye spread. However, invasion of the pink-eye pathogen into the eyes of infected birds caused shifts in resident microbial communities. Shifts were more minor for birds that were exposed to pathogen through their cagemates, rather than directly. These results suggest that resident microbial communities may be more resilient when pathogen exposure occurs through contact with contagious individuals, as in the wild. Overall, the outcomes of interactions between pathogens and resident microbial communities may depend on the mode or dose of pathogen exposure.

Because gut health has increasingly been shown to affect other tissues throughout the body, we next examined whether intestinal microbes help protect birds from pink-eye. We found that birds given oral antibiotics to disrupt intestinal microbes did not show more severe pink-eye. Instead, birds given oral antibiotics tended to show less severe pink-eye, even though the oral antibiotic that we gave birds cannot kill the pink-eye pathogen itself. One possibility is that oral antibiotic treatment reduced certain resident bacteria in the gut that contribute to host inflammation responses.

Finally, we sampled the resident microbes present in wild house finches and on the feeder surfaces they use. Relative to captive birds, free-living finches harbored more diverse microbes in their eyes and intestines. This suggests that captive studies of microbial protection, while critical, need to be complemented with studies of microbial variation on free-living animals. We also detected many microbes, including the bacteria that causes pink-eye, on feeder surfaces. This confirms that feeders can serve as key sources for microbial spread, both for harmful bacteria and resident microbes of birds.

Our work generated several key broader impacts. First, we trained 11 undergraduate students, 2 post-baccalaureate students, 5 graduate students, and 2 postdoctoral scholars as part of this project, exposing trainees to diverse approaches, including fieldwork, animal infection experiments, molecular-based lab work, and quantitative approaches. Second, we collaborated with the Science Museum of Southwest Virginia to design a microbes exhibit that will remain up indefinitely. This exhibit illustrates the diversity in form and function of microbes, and briefly summarizes our research on house finches. The museum receives over 90,000 visitors a year, allowing this exhibit to reach a broad audience in a part of the country with relatively little science education infrastructure. Finally, our project actively trained graduate students to communicate to a broader public about microbes and their benefits via workshops for a summer science camp and a suite of other venues designed to facilitate public engagement with science.
